", 'number': 32}, {'created': '2014-08-29 05:51:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Pool-aware Scheduler Support

This change introduces pool-aware scheduler to address the need for
supporting multiple pools from one storage controller.

Terminology
-----------
Pool - A logical concept to describe a set of storage resource that
can be used to serve core Cinder requests, e.g. volumes/snapshots.
This notion is almost identical to Cinder Volume Backend, for it
has simliar attributes (capacity, capability).  The main difference
is Pool couldn't exist on its own, it must reside in a Volume
Backend.  One Volume Backend can have mulitple Pools but Pools
don't have sub-Pools (meaning even they have, sub-Pools don't get
to exposed to Cinder, yet).  Pool has a unique name in backend
namespace, which means Volume Backend can't have two pools using
same name.
Legacy Volume - Volumes that were created prior pools are introduced.
There are several corner cases where legacy volumes could cause
issues, especially for those drivers used to do pools internally
(e.g. 3Par, NetApp).  Please refer to 'Limitation/Known Issues' for
details.

Design
------
The workflow in this change is simple:
 1) Volume Backends reports how many pools and what those pools
 look like and are capable of to scheduler;
 2) When request comes in, scheduler picks a pool that fits the need
 most to serve the request, it passes the request to the backend
 where the target pool resides in;
 3) Volume driver gets the message and let the target pool to serve
 the request as scheduler instructed.

To support placing resources (volume/snapshot) onto a pool, these
pieces in Cinder currently are missing:
1. Volume Backends reporting capacity/capabilities at pool level;
2. Scheduler filtering/weighing based on pool capacity/capability
and placing volumes/snapshots to a pool of certain backend;
3. Record which pool a resource is located on a backend and passes
between scheduler and volume backend.

The missing piece 1 is solved by a) updating the format of
periodical volume stats message to adopt pool stats; b) altering
manager/driver to collect and report pool stats.  Below is an example
of the updated report message that contains 2 pools:

    capability = {
        'volume_backend_name': 'Local iSCSI', #\
        'vendor_name': 'OpenStack',           #  backend level
        'driver_version': '1.0',              #  mandatory/fixed
        'storage_protocol': 'iSCSI',          #- stats&capabilities

        'active_volumes': 10,                 #\
        'IOPS_provisioned': 30000,            #  optional custom
        'fancy_capability_1': 'eat',          #  stats & capabilities
        'fancy_capability_2': 'drink',        #/

        'pools': [
            {'pool_name': '1st pool',         #\
             'total_capacity_gb': 500,        #  mandatory stats for
             'free_capacity_gb': 230,         #  pools
             'allocated_capacity_gb': 270,    # |
             'QoS_support': 'False',          # |
             'reserved_percentage': 0,        #/

             'dying_disks': 100,              #\
             'super_hero_1': 'spider-man',    #  optional custom
             'super_hero_2': 'flash',         #  stats & capabilities
             'super_hero_3': 'neoncat'        #/
             },
            {'pool_name': '2nd pool',
             'total_capacity_gb': 1024,
             'free_capacity_gb': 1024,
             'allocated_capacity_gb': 0,
             'QoS_support': 'False',
             'reserved_percentage': 0,

             'dying_disks': 200,
             'super_hero_1': 'superman',
             'super_hero_2': ' ',
             'super_hero_2': 'Hulk',
             }
        ]
    }

Notice that there are now two levels of mandatory/fixed stats &
capabilities that every volume driver should report.

The scheduler change is mostly done in scheduler/host_manager.py:
* HostState adds a list element to hold PoolState(s) (a HostState sub-
class).  Each PoolState can be treated like a HostState since it has
as much information as HostState and also share the same structure.
HostState.update_capabilities()/update_from_volume_capability() are
changed to handle both legacy and new report messages.
* HostManager.get_all_host_states() now returns a PoolState iterator
that includes all pools scheduler tracks.  To filters and weighers,
PoolState() and HostState() are identical, thus there is no need to
change filters and weighers since they are dealing with same kind of
information and exact same data strucuture as before.  What filter
and weigher deals with looks like this:
    # Before this change
      HostState() for Backend 1
         ...
      HostState() for Backend N
    # After this change
      PoolState() for Backend 1 Pool 1
         ...
      PoolState() for Backend 1 Pool N

        ...

      PoolState() for Backend N Pool 1
         ...
      PoolState() for Backend N Pool N

With this change, filter scheduler will pick a pool@host instead of a
host.

Now that we are able to report and decide at pool level, the 3rd
missing piece is easy to fix.  Just like how multi-backend
volume service is supported, we encoded pool name into 'host' field
of Volume table.  The 'host' field is now 'host@backend#pool'. Notice
that this change doesn't mean that cinder-volume service will have to
subscribe to multiple RPC channels.  There is no need to mess with
message queue subscription at all because we did a little trick when
determining RPC target in VolumeRPCAPI: correct host info like
'host@backend' is extracted from 'host@backend#pool' before sending
RPC messages.  Therefore, once scheduler decides which pool on a
backend shall serve a request, it updates 'host' field of the volume
record in DB to be like 'host@backend#pool', but it still sends RPC
message to 'host@backend' which cinder-volume is listening to.

Simliar action is done when creating backups for volumes.  host@backend
is extracted from volume['host'] so that correct backup service can be
picked.

Other changes are done in this patch:

* Change get_volume_stats() in ISCSIVolumeDriver/ISERDriver to include
pool stats, and change default total/free_capacity_gb from 'infinite'
to 0.
* Add logic in volume manager init_host() to detect legacy volumes and
try to update host info for them if driver is able to provide pool info.
* Add get_pool() driver API to return the pool name of given volume,
this help volume manager to handle legacy volumes, especially for those
backends already support pooling internally (e.g. 3Par, NetApp).
* Implement get_pool() for LVM driver to return volume backend name as
pool name.
* Add extract_host() helper function in cinder/volume/utils.py to help
handle cases where there is needs to extract 'host', 'backend' or
'pool' information from volume['host'].
* Add append_host() helper function in cinder/volume/utils.py to help
concatenate host and pool string into one for volume['host'] field.

Limitation/Known Issues
-----------------------
* The term 'host' in Cinder used to refer to 'backend', and it was
consistent from the view of end users/admins to Cinder internals.
Now that pool is exposed to Cinder scheduler, scheduler starts treating
different pools on same backend as different hosts.  Therefore, we have
to expose pool to admin at least, because migrating volume now has to
include pool in 'host' parameter in order to work.  As for end users,
the whole 'host' of volume equals storage backend idea works well for
them, so they can decide the policy of migration when retyping volumes,
or choose to create new volume on same or different host as/from
existing volumes.  Now it's *not* easy to hide pool from end user and
make retype or affinity filter work like before.  This change has a
speical code path for legacy volumes, to allow (potential) migration
between pools even migration_policy is set to 'never'.  But not every
driver has magic to move volumes to one pool to another at minimum
cost.  The inconsistency behavior between drivers (same command may
take totally different time to finish), which could be very confusing.

* Drivers want to support pools need to update, but they should work
just like they used to without any change except:
 - creating volume using same/different host hints with legacy volumes
 may NOT work as expected, because 'hostA' is considered different
 from 'hostA#pool0' and 'hostA#pool1'.  But legacy volume on 'hostA'
 might actually resides in pool0, only the driver has this knowledge.
 - retyping legacy volume issue as mentioned above.

Ultimate solution for all these corner cases is to update Cinder DB
to add 'pool' info for legacy volumes.  The problem is only the driver
knows such info, that is why we add a new driver API get_pool() to
so that volume manager is able to learn pool info from driver and
update host field of legacy volumes in DB.

User-Visible Change
-------------------
DocImpact
For managing and migrating volumes, now user needs to provide pool
information as part of host string. For example:
  cinder manage --source-name X --name newX host@backend#POOL
  cinder migrate UUID host@backend#POOL

* HostState adds a list element to hold PoolState(s) (a HostState sub-
class).  Each PoolState can be treated like a HostState since it has
as much information as HostState and also share the same structure.
HostState.update_capabilities()/update_from_volume_capability() are
changed to handle both legacy and new report messages.
* HostManager.get_all_host_states() now returns a PoolState iterator
that includes all pools scheduler tracks.  To filters and weighers,
PoolState() and HostState() are identical, thus there is no need to
change filters and weighers since they are dealing with same kind of
information and exact same data strucuture as before.  What filter
and weigher deals with looks like this:
    # Before this change
      HostState() for Backend 1
         ...
      HostState() for Backend N
    # After this change
      PoolState() for Backend 1 Pool 1
         ...
      PoolState() for Backend 1 Pool N

        ...

      PoolState() for Backend N Pool 1
         ...
      PoolState() for Backend N Pool N

With this change, filter scheduler will pick a pool@host instead of a
host.

Now that we are able to report and decide at pool level, the 3rd
missing piece is easy to fix.  Just like how multi-backend
volume service is supported, we encoded pool name into 'host' field
of Volume table.  The 'host' field is now 'host@backend#pool'. Notice
that this change doesn't mean that cinder-volume service will have to
subscribe to multiple RPC channels.  There is no need to mess with
message queue subscription at all because we did a little trick when
determining RPC target in VolumeRPCAPI: correct host info like
'host@backend' is extracted from 'host@backend#pool' before sending
RPC messages.  Therefore, once scheduler decides which pool on a
backend shall serve a request, it updates 'host' field of the volume
record in DB to be like 'host@backend#pool', but it still sends RPC
message to 'host@backend' which cinder-volume is listening to.

Simliar action is done when creating backups for volumes.  host@backend
is extracted from volume['host'] so that correct backup service can be
picked.

Other changes are done in this patch:

* Change get_volume_stats() in ISCSIVolumeDriver/ISERDriver to include
pool stats, and change default total/free_capacity_gb from 'infinite'
to 0.
* Add logic in volume manager init_host() to detect legacy volumes and
try to update host info for them if driver is able to provide pool info.
* Add get_pool() driver API to return the pool name of given volume,
this help volume manager to handle legacy volumes, especially for those
backends already support pooling internally (e.g. 3Par, NetApp).
* Implement get_pool() for LVM driver to return volume backend name as
pool name.
* Add extract_host() helper function in cinder/volume/utils.py to help
handle cases where there is needs to extract 'host', 'backend' or
'pool' information from volume['host'].
* Add append_host() helper function in cinder/volume/utils.py to help
concatenate host and pool string into one for volume['host'] field.

Limitation/Known Issues
-----------------------
* The term 'host' in Cinder used to refer to 'backend', and it was
consistent from the view of end users/admins to Cinder internals.
Now that pool is exposed to Cinder scheduler, scheduler starts treating
different pools on same backend as different hosts.  Therefore, we have
to expose pool to admin at least, because migrating volume now has to
include pool in 'host' parameter in order to work.  As for end users,
the whole 'host' of volume equals storage backend idea works well for
them, so they can decide the policy of migration when retyping volumes,
or choose to create new volume on same or different host as/from
existing volumes.  Now it's *not* easy to hide pool from end user and
make retype or affinity filter work like before.  This change has a
speical code path for legacy volumes, to allow (potential) migration
between pools even migration_policy is set to 'never'.  But not every
driver has magic to move volumes to one pool to another at minimum
cost.  The inconsistency behavior between drivers (same command may
take totally different time to finish), which could be very confusing.

* Drivers want to support pools need to update, but they should work
just like they used to without any change except:
 - creating volume using same/different host hints with legacy volumes
 may NOT work as expected, because 'hostA' is considered different
 from 'hostA#pool0' and 'hostA#pool1'.  But legacy volume on 'hostA'
 might actually resides in pool0, only the driver has this knowledge.
 - retyping legacy volume issue as mentioned above.

Ultimate solution for all these corner cases is to update Cinder DB
to add 'pool' info for legacy volumes.  The problem is only the driver
knows such info, that is why we add a new driver API get_pool() to
so that volume manager is able to learn pool info from driver and
update host field of legacy volumes in DB.

User-Visible Change
-------------------
DocImpact
For managing and migrating volumes, now user needs to provide pool
information as part of host string. For example:
  cinder manage --source-name X --name newX host@backend#POOL
  cinder migrate UUID host@backend#POOL

implement blueprint: pool-aware-cinder-scheduler

Change-Id: Id8eacb8baeb56558aa3d9de19402e2075822b7b4

commit_message:
Pool-aware Scheduler Support

This change introduces pool-aware scheduler to address the need for
supporting multiple pools from one storage controller.

Terminology
-----------
Pool - A logical concept to describe a set of storage resource that
can be used to serve core Cinder requests, e.g. volumes/snapshots.
This notion is almost identical to Cinder Volume Backend, for it
has simliar attributes (capacity, capability).  The main difference
is Pool couldn't exist on its own, it must reside in a Volume
Backend.  One Volume Backend can have mulitple Pools but Pools
don't have sub-Pools (meaning even they have, sub-Pools don't get
to exposed to Cinder, yet).  Pool has a unique name in backend
namespace, which means Volume Backend can't have two pools using
same name.
Legacy Volume - Volumes that were created prior pools are introduced.
There are several corner cases where legacy volumes could cause
issues, especially for those drivers used to do pools internally
(e.g. 3Par, NetApp).  Please refer to 'Limitation/Known Issues' for
details.

Design
------
The workflow in this change is simple:
 1) Volume Backends reports how many pools and what those pools
 look like and are capable of to scheduler;
 2) When request comes in, scheduler picks a pool that fits the need
 most to serve the request, it passes the request to the backend
 where the target pool resides in;
 3) Volume driver gets the message and let the target pool to serve
 the request as scheduler instructed.

To support placing resources (volume/snapshot) onto a pool, these
pieces in Cinder currently are missing:
1. Volume Backends reporting capacity/capabilities at pool level;
2. Scheduler filtering/weighing based on pool capacity/capability
and placing volumes/snapshots to a pool of certain backend;
3. Record which pool a resource is located on a backend and passes
between scheduler and volume backend.

The missing piece 1 is solved by a) updating the format of
periodical volume stats message to adopt pool stats; b) altering
manager/driver to collect and report pool stats.  Below is an example
of the updated report message that contains 2 pools:

    capability = {
        'volume_backend_name': 'Local iSCSI', #\
        'vendor_name': 'OpenStack',           #  backend level
        'driver_version': '1.0',              #  mandatory/fixed
        'storage_protocol': 'iSCSI',          #- stats&capabilities

        'active_volumes': 10,                 #\
        'IOPS_provisioned': 30000,            #  optional custom
        'fancy_capability_1': 'eat',          #  stats & capabilities
        'fancy_capability_2': 'drink',        #/

        'pools': [
            {'pool_name': '1st pool',         #\
             'total_capacity_gb': 500,        #  mandatory stats for
             'free_capacity_gb': 230,         #  pools
             'allocated_capacity_gb': 270,    # |
             'QoS_support': 'False',          # |
             'reserved_percentage': 0,        #/

             'dying_disks': 100,              #\
             'super_hero_1': 'spider-man',    #  optional custom
             'super_hero_2': 'flash',         #  stats & capabilities
             'super_hero_3': 'neoncat'        #/
             },
            {'pool_name': '2nd pool',
             'total_capacity_gb': 1024,
             'free_capacity_gb': 1024,
             'allocated_capacity_gb': 0,
             'QoS_support': 'False',
             'reserved_percentage': 0,

             'dying_disks': 200,
             'super_hero_1': 'superman',
             'super_hero_2': ' ',
             'super_hero_2': 'Hulk',
             }
        ]
    }

Notice that there are now two levels of mandatory/fixed stats &
capabilities that every volume driver should report.

The scheduler change is mostly done in scheduler/host_manager.py:
* HostState adds a list element to hold PoolState(s) (a HostState sub-
class).  Each PoolState can be treated like a HostState since it has
as much information as HostState and also share the same structure.
HostState.update_capabilities()/update_from_volume_capability() are
changed to handle both legacy and new report messages.
* HostManager.get_all_host_states() now returns a PoolState iterator
that includes all pools scheduler tracks.  To filters and weighers,
PoolState() and HostState() are identical, thus there is no need to
change filters and weighers since they are dealing with same kind of
information and exact same data strucuture as before.  What filter
and weigher deals with looks like this:
    # Before this change
      HostState() for Backend 1
         ...
      HostState() for Backend N
    # After this change
      PoolState() for Backend 1 Pool 1
         ...
      PoolState() for Backend 1 Pool N

        ...

      PoolState() for Backend N Pool 1
         ...
      PoolState() for Backend N Pool N

With this change, filter scheduler will pick a pool@host instead of a
host.

Now that we are able to report and decide at pool level, the 3rd
missing piece is easy to fix.  Just like how multi-backend
volume service is supported, we encoded pool name into 'host' field
of Volume table.  The 'host' field is now 'host@backend#pool'. Notice
that this change doesn't mean that cinder-volume service will have to
subscribe to multiple RPC channels.  There is no need to mess with
message queue subscription at all because we did a little trick when
determining RPC target in VolumeRPCAPI: correct host info like
'host@backend' is extracted from 'host@backend#pool' before sending
RPC messages.  Therefore, once scheduler decides which pool on a
backend shall serve a request, it updates 'host' field of the volume
record in DB to be like 'host@backend#pool', but it still sends RPC
message to 'host@backend' which cinder-volume is listening to.

Simliar action is done when creating backups for volumes.  host@backend
is extracted from volume['host'] so that correct backup service can be
picked.

Other changes are done in this patch:

* Change get_volume_stats() in ISCSIVolumeDriver/ISERDriver to include
pool stats, and change default total/free_capacity_gb from 'infinite'
to 0.
* Add logic in volume manager init_host() to detect legacy volumes and
try to update host info for them if driver is able to provide pool info.
* Add get_pool() driver API to return the pool name of given volume,
this help volume manager to handle legacy volumes, especially for those
backends already support pooling internally (e.g. 3Par, NetApp).
* Implement get_pool() for LVM driver to return volume backend name as
pool name.
* Add extract_host() helper function in cinder/volume/utils.py to help
handle cases where there is needs to extract 'host', 'backend' or
'pool' information from volume['host'].
* Add append_host() helper function in cinder/volume/utils.py to help
concatenate host and pool string into one for volume['host'] field.

Limitation/Known Issues
-----------------------
* The term 'host' in Cinder used to refer to 'backend', and it was
consistent from the view of end users/admins to Cinder internals.
Now that pool is exposed to Cinder scheduler, scheduler starts treating
different pools on same backend as different hosts.  Therefore, we have
to expose pool to admin at least, because migrating volume now has to
include pool in 'host' parameter in order to work.  As for end users,
the whole 'host' of volume equals storage backend idea works well for
them, so they can decide the policy of migration when retyping volumes,
or choose to create new volume on same or different host as/from
existing volumes.  Now it's *not* easy to hide pool from end user and
make retype or affinity filter work like before.  This change has a
speical code path for legacy volumes, to allow (potential) migration
between pools even migration_policy is set to 'never'.  But not every
driver has magic to move volumes to one pool to another at minimum
cost.  The inconsistency behavior between drivers (same command may
take totally different time to finish), which could be very confusing.

* Drivers want to support pools need to update, but they should work
just like they used to without any change except:
 - creating volume using same/different host hints with legacy volumes
 may NOT work as expected, because 'hostA' is considered different
 from 'hostA#pool0' and 'hostA#pool1'.  But legacy volume on 'hostA'
 might actually resides in pool0, only the driver has this knowledge.
 - retyping legacy volume issue as mentioned above.

Ultimate solution for all these corner cases is to update Cinder DB
to add 'pool' info for legacy volumes.  The problem is only the driver
knows such info, that is why we add a new driver API get_pool() to
so that volume manager is able to learn pool info from driver and
update host field of legacy volumes in DB.

User-Visible Change
-------------------
DocImpact
For managing and migrating volumes, now user needs to provide pool
information as part of host string. For example:
  cinder manage --source-name X --name newX host@backend#POOL
  cinder migrate UUID host@backend#POOL

implement blueprint: pool-aware-cinder-scheduler

commit_message:
Fix default want_result value for event_finish_with_failure

Fix instance action event object method to match with other object
methods. Invoking this method without specifying want_result argument
should return object built from db values.

Related to blueprint compute-manager-objects-juno

Change-Id: I5f8cd66e4de20e730bcb8aceb2b97c3173e3870b

commit_message:
Ensure using int type for revocation_cache_time

Once set revocation_cache_time option for auth_token middleware,
it needs to be convrt to int before consuming by datetime.timedelta
function. Otherwise will cause WSGI service with this auth_token
middleware to die.

Change-Id: I6f7698f1e01603b5ecfe8b28f2282f9a1a8737b0
Closes-Bug: #1354269

commit_message:
Fix service API and cells

The move to the object model broke the service API when used together
with cells. The underlying problem is how cells will overload the id
field with a cell path to uniquely identify each service in each cell.

Changing the id to a string would defeat the purpose of the object model
so this patch uses a proxy to modify the id on access to make the
difference transparent to the API.

Closes-bug: 1251043
(cherry picked from commit 0df94733f7283cbc1e9ae7d27f5cd443158cae8e)

Conflicts:

	nova/tests/api/openstack/compute/contrib/test_services.py
	nova/tests/api/openstack/compute/plugins/v3/test_services.py

Change-Id: I5c5c19fa1e8ed6f56a2851234ff8418447a562b1

commit_message:
Use oslo.i18n, properly mark LOG messages

oslo.i18n provides the i18n function that were provided by
oslo-incubator's gettextutils module.

Use _LE, _LW and _LI for logging of errors, warnings and info.

Import _ where needed, oslo.i18n deprecated the builtin method.

Fix concatenation of translated string with normal string.

Change-Id: I626c74d0bd4e8786770fa063adc4f174ff2c2c6d

commit_message:
Implement BlockDeviceMappings for LaunchConfiguration

We should support the BlockDeviceMappings for
AWS::AutoScaling::LaunchConfiguration resource to be
compatible with AWSCloudFormation, thus we can take
BlockDeviceMappings for instances in AutoScalingGroup
and InstanceGroup.

Implements blueprint implement-launchconfiguration-bdm

Change-Id: I26b13b8e98190fa4bb4223b5eed9970648d7ee35

Implements blueprint implement-ec2eip-updatable

Change-Id: Ifa883c31214c4cc367751766efcb6b775d1b4ffe

commit_message:
Fix delete failed because association creation failed

Modify if the eip association is not created successful,
don't try to delete it.

Implements blueprint implement-ec2eip-updatable

Change-Id: Ifa883c31214c4cc367751766efcb6b775d1b4ffe

commit_message:
Populate host field for cg in the unit test

The host field for consistencygroup is missing in the test.
As a result, the test failed when extract_host is called in
the pool aware scheduler patch:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/98715/34

Change-Id: I6ded78baa7eb5c640c9fce3303942c934663e4f9

commit_message:
Create SAML generation route and controller

In order to take advantage of the new SAML generation code, we
need to create a route and controller in OS-FEDERATION.

corresponding api spec: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/113998/

Implements: bp keystone-to-keystone-federation

Change-Id: Ib27921fa1fcff8760836e065ede1e90d1330fd16

commit_message:
Add client support in Cinder for volume replication

Provide Cinder client support to manage volume replication.
Cinder-specs available at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/98308/

Change-Id: Id60bacbcc113d42730e822b29b2fa78be94d3276
Implements: blueprint volume-replication

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-09-04 08:50:15.000000000', 'files': ['fuelweb_test/helpers/http.py'], 'message': "Add handling of 401 error from keystone (systests)

Sometimes after reverting VMs snapshots keystone client
can't get authorization token due to 401 unauthorized error.
We should handle this exception in tests and try to redo

Change-Id: I499855a6b13eacee4894a837d3170b9f550cf74d
Closes-bug: #1365376
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Add handling of 401 error from keystone (systests)

Sometimes after reverting VMs snapshots keystone client
can't get authorization token due to 401 unauthorized error.
We should handle this exception in tests and try to redo
keystone authorization.

Change-Id: I499855a6b13eacee4894a837d3170b9f550cf74d
Closes-bug: #1365376

commit_message:
Add Cisco FC Zoning plugin to the FC ZoneManager

The Cisco FC Zoning plugin allows for the automated creation,
deletion and modification of zones in zonesets.  The Cisco
FC zoning plugin supports both basic and enhanced zoning and
supports vsans.

Implements: blueprint cisco-fc-zone-driver
Change-Id: Icf176b6f46f1b1662f0a99ffaa226789661f611e

subject: Small Fix for FakeServerConnection
revisions:
[{'created': '2014-08-29 02:30:44.000000000', 'files': ['test/unit/proxy/test_sysmeta.py'], 'message': 'Small Fix for FakeServerConnection

Current FakeServerConnection might cause 499 error
in some unit tests because sent (put) data will be
overridden by new one every time.
e.g. When calling conn.queue.put() twice and more in
an object PUT sequence, we can use only a last chunk as
the body. This fixes it to merge all chunks as a body.

Change-Id: I463e9e2b454e3f3eb26950b3af4c8b8167a9a971
', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Small Fix for FakeServerConnection

Current FakeServerConnection might cause 499 error
in some unit tests because sent (put) data will be
overridden by new one every time.
e.g. When calling conn.queue.put() twice and more in
an object PUT sequence, we can use only a last chunk as
the body. This fixes it to merge all chunks as a body.

Change-Id: I463e9e2b454e3f3eb26950b3af4c8b8167a9a971

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-08-29 21:01:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Run unit tests against a particular git branch

Solum runs unit tests always against the master
branch, which does not reflect the real dev flow.

This patch focuses on the case of Github. So solum
trigger API is able to get a particular branch name
from request body sent by a Github webhook, and pass
it down to worker handler for running unit tests against
it.

Closes-bug: 1363249

Change-Id: I7ecdf626c99e16f9970ad4089020c95572c3da83

commit_message:
Run unit tests against a particular git branch

Solum runs unit tests always against the master
branch, which does not reflect the real dev flow.

This patch focuses on handling Github pull requests.
Solum trigger API is able to get a particular branch name
from request body sent by a Github webhook, and pass
it down to worker handler for running unit tests against
it.

Closes-bug: 1363249

Change-Id: I7ecdf626c99e16f9970ad4089020c95572c3da83

commit_message:
Use MultiStrOpt for policy_dirs

We want to ensure that the values specified for directory names are
treated as strings, so use MultiStrOpt instead of the more general
ListOpt.

Change-Id: I46ab5d768b434133f681d9348ecb4c271d633c21

  Change-Id: I1f0e93e1dee3d065c4f00d8bf2042bebc8d45a22
However, there is still sahara-dashboard in extras.d/70-sahara.sh. This
causes an error.

So this commit just removes it.

Closes-Bug: #1363828

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-09-03 21:29:12.000000000', 'files': ['keystone/tests/test_versions.py'], 'message': "use one indentation style

There are two (or three, depending on how you count) indentations styles
mixed together in this one logical line of code, which are further mixed
with two methods of closing parens and curly braces.

Besides being difficult to read, the mixture resulted in an off-by-one
error that isn't caught by the version of hacking that Jenkins is using,
but is caught by the latest.

Change-Id: Idab3c80c720e0bfd5741dc9e07f841b5ac270960
Closes-Bug: 1363019
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
use one indentation style

There are two (or three, depending on how you count) indentations styles
mixed together in this one logical line of code, which are further mixed
with two methods of closing parens and curly braces.

Besides being difficult to read, the mixture resulted in an off-by-one
error that isn't caught by the version of hacking that Jenkins is using,
but is caught by the latest.

Change-Id: Idab3c80c720e0bfd5741dc9e07f841b5ac270960
Closes-Bug: 1363019

commit_message:
Change v3 aggregate API to v2.1

This patch changes v3 aggregate API to v2.1 and makes v2
unit tests share between v2 and v2.1.

The differences between v2 and v3 are described on the wiki page
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/NovaAPIv2tov3.

Partially implements blueprint v2-on-v3-api

Change-Id: I95372d49ffacd12bdc8e2f6b60628c17f70d0eba

commit_message:
output-file option in stack-abandon

This patch adds --output-file, -O option in stack-abandon command.
If the option is specified, stack-abandon will output a result into
 the file.

Change-Id: Ic2518eae86d5f917d5227c6ab73062b665b5a89b
Closes-Bug: #1299023

subject: Split requirements into py2 and py3 files
revisions:
[{'created': '2014-08-15 19:33:46.000000000', 'files': ['README.rst', 'tox-tmpl.ini', 'requirements-py2.txt', 'requirements-py3.txt', 'tox.ini'], 'message': 'Split requirements into py2 and py3 files

Since PBR now supports distinguishing between
a requirements file for py2 and a different requirements
file for py3 we should add the support for that separation
so that it is easier to package taskflow.

Change-Id: I3c5faa99a529bcb28aa0276b8d345a26f94b5af3
', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Split requirements into py2 and py3 files

Since PBR now supports distinguishing between
a requirements file for py2 and a different requirements
file for py3 we should add the support for that separation
so that it is easier to package taskflow.

Change-Id: I3c5faa99a529bcb28aa0276b8d345a26f94b5af3

commit_message:
Avoid usage of insecure mktemp() function

This patch eliminates the use of the deprecated and insecure
tempfile.mktemp() function.  It has been replaced with secure
alternatives where temporary files are actually required.

Change-Id: I0a13d6d44cd1abc4b66fa33f39eea407617a01d5
SecurityImpact
Closes-bug: #1348869

this patch also adds 'glusterfs' as a supported protocol.

manila project with GlusterFS implementation is located @

commit_message:
Add support for cert-based access type

This patch adds support for cert-based access type.
The access_to parameter represents certificate's CN
(aka common name) to which access is denied or allowed
by the backend.

Partially-implements blueprint cert-based-access-type

Change-Id: I70c21397028e642bcf018ff254466046e38dcc3a

commit_message:
Changes V3 evacuate extension into v2.1

This patch changes v3 evacuate API to v2.1, and also share v2.1 and v2
test case.
The differences between v2 and v3 are described on the wiki page

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/NovaAPIv2tov3 .
Partially implements blueprint v2-on-v3-api

Change-Id: Ib105e367be5a921f1b9cade51204b224d99343ec

This a tiny change to make the observer behave more as you might
expect an auditing/diagnostic client to behave when obeserving
a task distribution queue.

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-09-01 13:40:01.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/plugins/mlnx/rpc_callbacks.py'], 'message': 'Fix a bug in Mellanox plugin RPC caused by secgroup RPC refactoring

SecurityGroupsRpcCallback RPC refactoring patch (commit 2781fce238)
moves get_port_from_device method from plugin RPC callback class to
plugin layer, but Mellanox plugin RPC callback was forgot to update
and as a result RPC calls from agents to Mellanox plugin fails.

Change-Id: I1aa82ac00c16a53a59a93087f0ca4ef281ee3f2b
Related-Bug: #1359416
', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Fix a bug in Mellanox plugin RPC caused by secgroup RPC refactoring

SecurityGroupsRpcCallback RPC refactoring patch (commit 2781fce238)
moves get_port_from_device method from plugin RPC callback class to
plugin layer, but Mellanox plugin RPC callback was forgot to update
and as a result RPC calls from agents to Mellanox plugin fails.

Change-Id: I1aa82ac00c16a53a59a93087f0ca4ef281ee3f2b
Related-Bug: #1359416

commit_message:
Use correct class path for token persistence backend

Keystone has moved over to using a new location for the token
persistence backends (drivers). The old values will continue to
work, but this will limit the deprecation warnings for an out
of the box devstack install.

Change-Id: I7c437788c8aee0106fa7f3c37617fbd1220291ef
bp: non-persistent-tokens

commit_message:
Watch .gitignore and check mimetype of files

Follow the rules set-out in .gitignore (based on the upstream code)
and only match files that seem to have a mime-type of a shell script.

Change-Id: I0df65e8e3a2ac77b720100715645fe9e7a84bf44

commit_message:
Updates to EC Design Spec

Based on conference call on 8/23, several updates were made
mainly to the reconstructor section as described in the
revision history.

Also added a section in the Reconstructor area on concurrency.

Change-Id: I9cdc22de645647ef14bbd1f9b69fa65c6d14eeb3
Implements: blueprint swift-ec

commit_message:
Use anyjson if available

The anyjson picks the best/fastest json parser
than is what is included by default in python
so we should try to use it if it is available
and if not then just fallback to using the native
python one.

Co-Authored-By: Andrey Kurilin <akurilin@mirantis.com>
Change-Id: I1001bfb0d84a19a6d1ca3f1265965e86ac09b551

commit_message:
Properly detect grenade in check_logs script

The check logs script was not properly detecting grenade and would fail
grenade jobs if the logs were not clean. We don't want to do this
because the upgrade process is not log clean yet. Correct this by
setting grenade flag to true only if the DEVSTACK_GATE_GRENADE variable
has content.

Change-Id: Id8a339d78d981376b9af3a80aae8e4e18a68a85f

', 'number': 4}, {'created': '2014-08-05 08:37:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Add QoS support to IBM Storwize driver

IBM Storwize driver can be enabled with QoS support by setting the parameter
I/O throttling rate, which caps the amount of I/O.

This patch add the QoS configuration to the methods of create_volume,
create_volume_from_snapshot, create_snapshot, create_cloned_volume and retype.

', 'number': 24}, {'created': '2014-08-28 07:12:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Add QoS support to IBM Storwize driver

IBM Storwize driver can be enabled with QoS support by setting the parameter
I/O throttling rate, which caps the amount of I/O.

This patch add the QoS configuration to the methods of create_volume,
create_volume_from_snapshot, create_cloned_volume and retype.

The QoS for IBM Storwize storage can be configured in 3 ways:
* Add the key "qos:IOThrottling" into a QoS spec and associate this QoS
spec with a volume type.
* Add the key "qos:IOThrottling" into the extra spec of a volume type.
* Add a metadata with the key "qos:IOThrottling".

Change-Id: I7c5c6726a61efad6a8ada9c5dcc31a9382ec79f9
implements-blueprint: cinder-storwize-driver-qos

commit_message:
Add QoS support to IBM Storwize driver

IBM Storwize driver can be enabled with QoS support by setting the parameter
I/O throttling rate, which caps the amount of I/O.

This patch add the QoS configuration to the methods of create_volume,
create_volume_from_snapshot, create_cloned_volume and retype.

The QoS for IBM Storwize storage can be configured in 3 ways:
* Add the key "qos:IOThrottling" into a QoS spec and associate this QoS
spec with a volume type.
* Add the key "qos:IOThrottling" into the extra spec of a volume type.
* Add a metadata with the key "qos:IOThrottling".

Change-Id: I7c5c6726a61efad6a8ada9c5dcc31a9382ec79f9
implements-blueprint: cinder-storwize-driver-qos

Before this patch, context was created in benchmark.runner
base. This patch moved context creation to benchmark.engine.

This change makes the architecture of Rally much cleaner.
e.g. runners don't know anything about benchmark context
(removing one dependency in code)

In addition, getting named meta information from benchmark.

commit_message:
Moved context creation to benchmark.engine

Before this patch, context was created in benchmark.runner
base. This patch moved context creation to benchmark.engine.

This change makes the architecture of Rally much cleaner.
e.g. runners don't know anything about benchmark context
(removing one dependency in code)

In addition, getting named meta information from benchmark.
scenarios.base will return a deepcopy to prevent accidental
changes of the returned object.

Conflicts:
	rally/benchmark/engine.py
	rally/benchmark/runners/base.py
	tests/benchmark/test_engine.py

Change-Id: I5af6edee2815dbddc371c126073474b9aa91d717

commit_message:
Bump pyeclib >= 0.9.5 for Swift Erasure Code project

Swift-EC design is based on the API in pyeclib 0.9.5 currently. It's not
working on < 0.9.5. We should follow the new version.

Change-Id: I257c6c784e1c786f6552c11191c3b4ef2bc8b53e

commit_message:
Replace explicit assertion for function

In order to reduce the verbosity and repetition when checking the json
schema, there was a function written that does this: It asserts that the
given json input is compliant witht he schema, and throws a proper
exception if possible. Most of the instances of this pattern were
already replaced in the code, but it seems there was one missing (or was
added later). So it was rightly replaced.

Change-Id: Ic9af4ac71c9d91a2083fccd67ca3901859f427e5

commit_message:
send paramiko logs to a file "paramiko.log"

This change adds a WatchedFileHandler for the paramiko logs to be
collected during tempest runs. We have encountered gate bugs [1]
related to SSH public key authentication and the paramiko logs
would be a great help for debugging.

The logs must also be collected by infra in order to be seen,
and the patch for that is here:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/118947

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/grenade/+bug/1349617

Change-Id: I7853fe1aa0c61a43b6de10ff25b18e20ad193e32

commit_message:
Add support for flashing ILO BMC's from ramdisks

This is more than a bit hard to test, requiring as it does an actual
iLO BMC, so sadly I have no tests :(.

HP Hardware really wants to be running latest firmware, and its
commonly agreed that one place where it can be sanely applied is in
the deploy environment, so this is my long threatened implementation
of that.

Change-Id: I3117a250d0d0eb8ee33eb4b15c837485a5cbf476

commit_message:
Fix some LOG invocations and messages

LOG.xxx("Hello %s" % xyz) should be LOG.xxx("Hello %s", xyz).
This allows the logging package to skip creating the
formatted log message if the message is not going to be emitted because
of the current log level.

The change touches error, warning and info LOG messages.

Adjust test suite for the above change since LOG now uses two parameters
instead of one.

Fix grammar, add missing "." to log messages in some places.

Change-Id: I86404c34502f07ed6dbda1c82b13db888c60f074

commit_message:
Convert v3 hypervisor plugin to v2.1

This patch convert v3 hypervisor plugin to v2.1 and makes v2
unit tests share between v2 and v2.1.

Unit tests has been modified in optimized way.

The differences between v2 and v3 are described on the wiki page
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/NovaAPIv2tov3.

Partially implements blueprint v2-on-v3-api

commit_message:
Fixes Hyper-V agent issue on Hyper-V 2008 R2

The vmutils.HyperVUtils class used on versions of Hyper-V prior of 2012
is missing the "remove_all_security_rules" method.

Change-Id: Ib14e643c400b230c912589f9480acf59d6e7b147
Closes-Bug: #1360817

subject: Add support for policy configration directories
revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-08 06:08:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "[WIP] Add support for policy configration directories

This patch add new option 'policy_configration_directories' and
restructure Enforcer.load_rules to loads policy files from directories
that specified by 'policy_configration_directories'.

UpgradeImpact:
Because the default value of 'policy_configration_directories' is
'policy.d', when deployer update the code, the deployer need create
directory for 'policy.d', otherwise an error will be raised.

Change-Id: I5218c6fa5f678e1c49b055b7ea351d202ea33e0b

commit_message:
Add support for policy configration directories

This patch add new option 'policy_dirs' and restructure
Enforcer.load_rules to loads policy files from directories that
specified by 'policy_dirs'.

Implement bp policy-configuration-directories

Change-Id: I5218c6fa5f678e1c49b055b7ea351d202ea33e0b

commit_message:
Interactive console support for ipminative driver

This patch adds interactive serial console support for ipminative
driver using shellinaboxd and pyghmi. A new class called
NativeIPMIShellinaboxConsole implements the ConsoleInterface.

Closes-Bug: 1359758
Change-Id: I9117c695af40044491fb7f213aa15e841e803d1c

commit_message:
Driver for Fusion-io ioControl Hybrid array

Standard Cinder driver for iSCSI target array.
Uses REST API of the ioControl array.
Implements Quality of Service through the 5 Policies avaliable on the array.
Add Apache License block
Test results: https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1317248

Change-Id: I27fdaedb9f75629a6af625f4e1c7d3f89a8cbb48
Implements: blueprint fusion-io-iocontrol-driver

owner_name: Chris Hoge (not involved in upstream development)
commit_message:
Add dependency on nova-common to ceilometer agent.

The ceilometer compute agent requires that the 'nova' group
be present. Since nova is no longer handling user and group
installation, some dependency must be established to make sure
basic nova packages are present.

The dependency chain now adds Package['nova-common'] as a
requirement for Packate['ceilometer-common'], which will
ensure that Nova and it's user/group will be created before
the nova group is added to the ceilometer user.

Fixes bug 1350980

Change-Id: I3601cc2be851e607c24a28f935387aa172542b00

subject: Pull flavor_ref from config for javelin servers
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 1420, 'name': 'Adam Gandelman', 'email': 'adamg@ubuntu.com', 'username': 'gandelman-a'}, {'_account_id': 1849, 'name': 'Joe Gordon', 'email': 'joe.gordon0@gmail.com', 'username': 'jogo'}, {'_account_id': 5196, 'name': 'Matthew Treinish', 'email': 'mtreinish@kortar.org', 'username': 'treinish'}, {'_account_id': 8871, 'name': 'Elastic Recheck', 'username': 'elasticrecheck'}, {'_account_id': 10385, 'name': 'Citrix XenServer CI', 'username': 'citrix_xenserver_ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2014-08-14 22:09:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Pull flavor_ref from config for javelin servers

The flavor used by Javelin to create servers should not be hard-coded
like the other resources as it is not created and managed by Javelin.
Some test environments require booting test servers using specific
flavors. This instead relies on the flavor_ref configured in tempest.conf,
which is assumed to be an existent and functional flavor setup by admin,
devstack, etc.

Change-Id: I4f0ba318e5de36764a1a41948b2da43eb03a3b7e
', 'number': 1}, {'created': '2014-08-19 19:22:27.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/cmd/javelin.py', 'tempest/cmd/resources.yaml'], 'message': 'Pull flavor_ref from config for javelin servers

javelin2 provides no facilities for creating/checking/deleting flavors
and shoult not allow resources to be specified in its yaml config if
it is not managing them entirely. This instead relies on the flavor_ref
configured in tempest.conf, which is assumed to be an existent flavor and
functional flavor setup by admin, devstack, etc.

Change-Id: I4f0ba318e5de36764a1a41948b2da43eb03a3b7e
', 'number': 2}]
commit_message:
Pull flavor_ref from config for javelin servers

javelin2 provides no facilities for creating/checking/deleting flavors
and shoult not allow resources to be specified in its yaml config if
it is not managing them entirely. This instead relies on the flavor_ref
configured in tempest.conf, which is assumed to be an existent flavor and
functional flavor setup by admin, devstack, etc.

Change-Id: I4f0ba318e5de36764a1a41948b2da43eb03a3b7e

commit_message:
Decouple OS services from boot-stack element

This spec describes required changes to various projects that would decouple
the OpenStack service topology from the central boot-stack element and its
operations.

Change-Id: I2f1a1ff7269877a34ca429e61cd19f83d348391b

[{'created': '2014-07-12 00:08:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Explicitly set required services in devtest

We currently pull in the required OpenStack services for a cloud implicitly
via boot-stack's element-deps in DIB.  Instead, we can state these as explicit
lists in the various stages of devtest. This is a first step toward allowing
services to be split out of the controller nodes and onto their own machines.
Later, we can expose these lists to boot-stack and other components of the
deployment via Heat.

We currently pull in the required OpenStack services for a cloud implicitly
via boot-stack's element-deps in DIB.  Instead, we can state these as explicit
lists in the various stages of devtest. This is a first step toward allowing
services to be split out of the controller nodes and onto their own machines.
Later, we can expose these lists to boot-stack and other components of the

Change-Id: Ia6b1d344b1d3ee0f226a8b6db0700e79feb0d7e9

commit_message:
Explicitly set required services in devtest

We currently pull in the required OpenStack services for a cloud implicitly
via boot-stack's element-deps in DIB.  Instead, we can state these as explicit
lists in the various stages of devtest. This is a first step toward allowing
services to be split out of the controller nodes and onto their own machines.
Later, we can expose these lists to boot-stack and other components of the
deployment via Heat.

Change-Id: Ia6b1d344b1d3ee0f226a8b6db0700e79feb0d7e9
Partial-bug: #1340467

commit_message:
Hack in pending upstream eventlet patch DONT MERGE

Pulls in some proposed changes to upstream eventlet into the ironic venv
that work around eventlet+paramiko issues (LP: #1321787) that seem tickled
during stack update/server rebuild.  These changes are (hopefully) slated for
inclusion in eventlet 0.16.  This is meant only to unblock testing.

Change-Id: I894525a681d2b7b3757ebe0d856ba9109c1e3fa4

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-21 17:06:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'package-installs for pre-install.d/post-install.d

Packages are often also installed in both the pre-install.d and
post-install.d phases. This patch expands the package-installs element
to support declarative package support for these phases in addition to
the existing support for install.d. The actual install/uninstall logic
is moved to common scripts under bin/ so that it can be reused across
the different phases.

Change-Id: Id51d0bbad232737fc8b5ffaf016dec50cd5b66c9

commit_message:
package-installs for pre-install.d/post-install.d

Packages are often also installed in both the pre-install.d and
post-install.d phases. This patch expands the package-installs element
to support declarative package support for these phases in addition to
the existing support for install.d. The actual install/uninstall logic
is moved to common scripts under bin/ so that it can be reused across
the different phases.

Change-Id: Id51d0bbad232737fc8b5ffaf016dec50cd5b66c9

commit_message:
Use ClusteredComputeManager for Ironic

Ironic ships its own compute manager slightly tailored for deploying
baremetal.  This enables it when VIRT_DRIVER=ironic and helps ensure
we test this as part of Ironic's CI pipeline.

Change-Id: I5fe8d6133cd0bc2585b22a3c353aaa68063b1941

commit_message:
Adds SingleInstanceFilter Nova scheduler filter

This adds a simple SingleInstanceFilter to the Nova scheduler filters.
It ensures a single instance-to-node mapping in the scheduler and does
not allow new instances to be scheduled to nodes that are already hosting
one, regardless of the node's hardware properties and calculated available
resources.

Change-Id: I09c6da387d7d5d53e15e4eeadb49c4b84d596300
Closes-bug: #1301279.

commit_message:
Makes kombu_ssl_* parameters optional when rabbit_use_ssl => true

The kombu_ssl_* parameters should not be required when rabbit_use_ssl => true
Rather, rabbit_use_ssl must be set to true if the kombu_ssl_* parameters are
used.

Change-Id: I3ce6a1a271efc560fedce9456489f5bc98ca00b9
Closes-Bug: 1356083

[{'created': '2014-08-28 22:07:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "stop locking skipping of busy instances during _sync_power_states

This change moves the logic for skipping instances with pending tasks
during a _sync_power_states call outside of the lock as it can cause
other periodic tasks to get backed up behind it.

It seems safe not to lock around the task_state check for a skip
because the instance object was read before the locking and isn't
being refreshed anyway.

Closes-Bug: #1362194

commit_message:
stop locking skipping of busy instances during _sync_power_states

This change moves the logic for skipping instances with pending tasks
during a _sync_power_states call outside of the lock as it can cause
other periodic tasks to get backed up behind it.

It seems safe not to lock around the task_state check for a skip
because the instance object was read before the locking and isn't
being refreshed anyway.

Closes-Bug: #1362194
Change-Id: Ia2c4603da66ccd5ae511ebf87b32a09cebe81aaa

subject: Mask passwords in exceptions and error messages
revisions:
[{'created': '2014-09-02 19:48:42.000000000', 'files': ['tests/unit/test_processutils.py', 'openstack/common/processutils.py'], 'message': 'Mask passwords in exceptions and error messages

When a ProcessExecutionError is thrown by processutils.ssh_execute(),
the exception may contain information such as password. Upstream
applications that just log the message (as several appear to do) could
inadvertently expose these passwords to a user with read access to the
log files. It is therefore considered prudent to invoke
strutils.mask_password() on the command, stdout and stderr in the
exception. A test case has been added to ensure that all three are
properly masked.

An earlier commit (I173dfb865e84eb7dee54a22c76db1e4f125a0a8a) failed
to address ssh_execute(). This change set addresses ssh_execute.

Submitted to oslo.concurrency in
I0db9e98cbeb2a5e6f9ae0074f24717aa91cfc238

OSSA is aware of this change request.

Change-Id: Ie0caf32469126dd9feb44867adf27acb6e383958
Closes-Bug: #1343604
', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Mask passwords in exceptions and error messages

When a ProcessExecutionError is thrown by processutils.ssh_execute(),
the exception may contain information such as password. Upstream
applications that just log the message (as several appear to do) could
inadvertently expose these passwords to a user with read access to the
log files. It is therefore considered prudent to invoke
strutils.mask_password() on the command, stdout and stderr in the
exception. A test case has been added to ensure that all three are
properly masked.

An earlier commit (I173dfb865e84eb7dee54a22c76db1e4f125a0a8a) failed
to address ssh_execute(). This change set addresses ssh_execute.

Submitted to oslo.concurrency in
I0db9e98cbeb2a5e6f9ae0074f24717aa91cfc238

OSSA is aware of this change request.

Change-Id: Ie0caf32469126dd9feb44867adf27acb6e383958
Closes-Bug: #1343604

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-08-14 20:32:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Make ssh-host-key-policy configurable

This patch adds configuration options for ssh_hosts_key_file and
strict_ssh_host_key_policy.  You can set strict_ssh_host_key_policy
to 'True' or 'False'.  If set to false the first connection of a host
will cause it to be added to the known_hosts file.  Subsequent connections
will be enforced against the existing key.  Changes in the key are assumed
to be a Man-in-the-Middle attack so the connection is rejected.

If strict_ssh_host_key_policy is 'True' the key for the host that is
being connected to must be in the hosts_key_file.  No first connection
assumptions are made.

strict_ssh_host_key_policy is set to 'False' to keep functionality similar
to the existing functionality.

With this patch, a default of ~cinder/.ssh/known_hosts is used for the
known_hosts file.  Unlike the previous approach, this now requires the
user to have a known_hosts file that is writable, somewhere.  The option
is configurable if they don't want to use ~cinder/.ssh/

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ia7a747224dbb08528f3c7a51da4cd4a6bf0eac1c
Implements-blueprint: configurable-ssh-host-key-policy

commit_message:
Make ssh-host-key-policy configurable

This patch adds configuration options for ssh_hosts_key_file and
strict_ssh_host_key_policy.  You can set strict_ssh_host_key_policy
to 'True' or 'False'.  If set to false the first connection of a host
will cause it to be added to the known_hosts file.  Subsequent connections
will be enforced against the existing key.  Changes in the key are assumed
to be a Man-in-the-Middle attack so the connection is rejected.

If strict_ssh_host_key_policy is 'True' the key for the host that is
being connected to must be in the hosts_key_file.  No first connection
assumptions are made.

strict_ssh_host_key_policy is set to 'False' to keep functionality similar
to the existing functionality.

With this patch, a default of $state_path/ssh_known_hosts is used for the
known_hosts file.  Unlike the previous approach, this now requires the
user to have a known_hosts file that is writable, somewhere.  The option
is configurable if they don't want to use $state_path/ssh_known_hosts

DocImpact:  Need to document the new strict_ssh_host_key_policy as well
as the ssh_hosts_key_file.  A note should be made for drivers that may
pass a hosts_key_file via kwargs when creating an ssh pool: their file
will be loaded along with the file configured via /etc/cinder.conf.
Also worth noting, for development environments, an ssh_hosts_key_file of
/dev/null and a strict_ssh_host_key_policy setting of 'False' may be used.
Using those setting will ignore these changes.

Change-Id: Ia7a747224dbb08528f3c7a51da4cd4a6bf0eac1c
Implements-blueprint: configurable-ssh-host-key-policy

commit_message:
Nova review updates for _node_resource

In review https://review.openstack.org/#/c/111425/14 it has been
raised that if the cpu_arch is not set, we should be using Nova
helper functions instead of 'NotFound'.  Also we should be
canonicalizing the user provided config value.

Once this is approved and merged, it will be proposed back into
the Nova tree.

Change-Id: Idfe0730daa22c6550a1a15b45f481635d2eb5195

commit_message:
Refactor object PUT to make EC easier to add

EC fragment archives need to go on the right primary nodes; that is,
fragment archive 0 needs to go on primary node 0, 1 on 1, and so
forth. Handoff nodes, however, are unordered.

This commit plumbs the index through to the proxy ObjectController's
PUT method as well as adds a (very simple) transform for replicated
data storage. Hopefully, this provides an easy integration point for
EC to use.

Change-Id: I72e6f313b12d7d4611fd95109ba66c8df8c8fa0f

There is no locking policy configured
for SSH failed login attempts in Fuel
for Openstack environments and that is
a major security issue.
Pam_tally2 module should be used in
order to lock user accounts after

attempts made to the system,

commit_message:
Blueprint: ssh-pam-tally2

There is no locking policy configured
for SSH failed login attempts in Fuel
for Openstack environments and that is
a major security issue.
Pam_tally2 module should be used in
order to lock user accounts after
certain number of failed ssh login
attempts made to the system,
and unlock it later as well.

Change-Id: I6fd90f582059213e25e555b8468af45d732dc7ca
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Adding initial update logic for orders

Adding the ability to update orders for certificates
in the controller. Connects the update order all the way
to the certificate resources. Also updated an issue
if order type was not listed, nothing would happen.

Implements: blueprint add-ssl-ca-support
Change-Id: I08e58cc618c5e21520f4d46cc35e10da1a02d0c8

commit_message:
Update netaddr to 0.7.12 version for IPv6

Netaddr below 0.7.12 can not check IPv6 subnets for overlapping
It causes neutron to fail.

Change-Id: I139f51d2ef49d27e6ae29fe551df31c981653e7c
Closes-Bug: 1364166

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-08-07 20:51:13.000000000', 'files': ['elements/nova-kvm/install.d/nova-source-install/80-nova-kvm'], 'message': 'Switch nova-kvm to use pip libvirt-python

When using source installs we can now switch to use

', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Switch nova-kvm to use pip libvirt-python

When using source installs we can now switch to use
libvirt-python from pypi. This will allow us to fully
isolate the Nova venv (should we choose to do so).

See also nova commit 8f505b85268adc226ec0a83826c2d13edcbe3d7c

Change-Id: I8a718e59c8627902de0e09c32d3952f598407860

commit_message:
Update list of oslo libs in update.py

We have to track the list of oslo libs so we do not rewrite references
to them when syncing modules from the incubator. This change moves the
list to a variable and adds several of the missing libraries.

Change-Id: I493c09f285da9360a527109c14be2ff22f70b543

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-08-07 15:03:52.000000000', 'files': ['elements/tripleo-cd/deploy-ci-overcloud', 'elements/tripleo-cd/configs/overcloud_hp1rc'], 'message': "Don't hardcode deploy-ci-overcloud to HP

This patch makes the deploy-ci-overcloud script generic.

The hard coded HP specific configs have been moved out of the
deploy-ci-overcloud script and into a bash rc file in the configs
directory.

The deploy-ci-overcloud script now takes a bash rc file
as a argument (which it sources)

Change-Id: I0d8270c586140f5840ce3713750ec87f55c2447a
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Don't hardcode deploy-ci-overcloud to HP

This patch makes the deploy-ci-overcloud script generic.

The hard coded HP specific configs have been moved out of the
deploy-ci-overcloud script and into a bash rc file in the configs
directory.

The deploy-ci-overcloud script now takes a bash rc file
as a argument (which it sources)

Change-Id: I0d8270c586140f5840ce3713750ec87f55c2447a

commit_message:
Increases the AWS::ElasticLoadBalancing::LoadBalancer Timeout

Previously, the AWS::ElasticLoadBalancing::LoadBalancer resource
waithandle would timeout after 600 seconds.  This causes the
default load_balancer template to fail when using slower
network connections.

Change-Id: I7e37e6633f2de91891e7ea7eee91bc0d73b8251c
Closes-Bug: #1240565

commit_message:
Use 8GiB swift storage with tempest

"No space left on" appeared in the swift proxy log,
increasing the size to 8GiB.

Several tempest test using 2 GiB swift storage.
The original calculation made with 1 GiB.

The tempest test will be changed to reduce the theoretical
peak usage, but 8GiB will be required when we increase the
number of workers.

This simple change expected to solve or mitigate
 the leading gate failure.

Related-Bug: #1347692

Change-Id: I11c060fe5d462fa9ef37348be75d6125868529be

commit_message:
Switch Redis driver modules over to oslo.utils.timeutils

This patch changes the Redis drivers so they use the oslo.utils
version of timeutils. This is consistent with the rest of Zaqar.

Change-Id: I56379b90414cbd8bcc6bca6998988dba800693b9
Partially-Implements: blueprint redis-storage-driver

commit_message:
Calculate stats dynamically instead of using side counters

Side counters are error-prone, and there are cases where they can
get out of sync if we lose a connection to the DB at the wrong
moment. Also, they are difficult to update when performing GC
operations.

This patch mostly removes the use of counters to track stats and
does the calculations on the fly. These calculations should still be
quite fast, since we are still using a per-claim counter (which
is easier to maintain than the per-queue counters).

Change-Id: I5d63a3791afd8d749890c5996208568c974f71d1
Partially-Implements: blueprint redis-storage-driver

commit_message:
Update minimum pip version to avoid failure

Currently, in install_venv_common.py, pip is upgraded like so:

self.pip_install('pip>=1.4')

Unfortunately, if any value of pip<1.5 is used, the pip install of
oslosphinx fails.

pip install --upgrade oslosphinx\>=2.2.0.0a2
Downloading/unpacking oslosphinx>=2.2.0.0a2
  Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement
oslosphinx>=2.2.0.0a2 (from versions: 2.0, 2.1.0)
Cleaning up...
No distributions matching the version for oslosphinx>=2.2.0.0a2
Storing complete log in /Users/mwood/.pip/pip.log

Thus, the minimum value of pip within install_venv_common.py should be upped
to 1.5

Change-Id: Ibe1396721f4af9dc8cb9722e1b1231231cd93273
Closes-Bug: 119086

commit_message:
Allow specifying Nova, Cinder and Swift endpoints

In Icehouse, Trove wasn't able to query Keystone for the
endpoints for those services yet, they had to be set in the
configuration files.

Change-Id: Ia4464652e0e4b05e89011295855de0bfc5be1be1

commit_message:
Add $package_ensure to glance::backend::rbd

Previously for the python-ceph package ensure was hard coded to 'present', but
in some circumstances we want to set the ensure value same as for the glance
package itself.  This adds that in.

Change-Id: Ib5fc0b3d916eef93c810b0ee3fcecf0d9b80218e

commit_message:
Unescape value in parse_allocation_pool

Neutron in Fedora 21 changed library for formating shell output and
it's now escaped. We just make sure we'll unescape it before applying
regexp.

Change-Id: I56f1f05576fe4d2dde5d1d59184b03d0ad244783

commit_message:
Implement the rest of Swift containers and objects

This change adds support for Swift objects and updates some of the
container implementation. At this point, full CRUD support for Swift is
basically implemented save for adding user-defined headers.

Change-Id: Icbaffb5d76bfd1977ab7213a9b83bc28cf0bc551

subject: Handle py26 ImportError in custom_matchers
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 9492, 'name': 'Yi Ming Yin', 'email': 'yinym@cn.ibm.com', 'username': 'yym'}, {'_account_id': 10385, 'name': 'Citrix XenServer CI', 'username': 'citrix_xenserver_ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 10624, 'name': 'Brocade ADX CI', 'username': 'pattabi-ayyasami-ci', 'inactive': True, 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2014-08-29 21:21:59.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/common/custom_matchers.py'], 'message': "Handle py26 ImportError in custom_matchers

Commit b6e1a28cd7c0df9ae6f2d86e18733f38bd5b5548 adds
the import of unittest.util which is only in python
2.7, so this will fail if running Tempest on python
2.6, e.g. RHEL/CentOS 6.5.

There is already some unit test code in Tempest using
unittest2 so this isn't novel and will presumably be
removed in Kilo when the community drops py26 support.

Change-Id: I5e864a0d1dde8a1ff524d1d806a66d01bfb9cb5d
Closes-Bug: #1363262
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Handle py26 ImportError in custom_matchers

Commit b6e1a28cd7c0df9ae6f2d86e18733f38bd5b5548 adds
the import of unittest.util which is only in python
2.7, so this will fail if running Tempest on python
2.6, e.g. RHEL/CentOS 6.5.

There is already some unit test code in Tempest using
unittest2 so this isn't novel and will presumably be
removed in Kilo when the community drops py26 support.

Change-Id: I5e864a0d1dde8a1ff524d1d806a66d01bfb9cb5d
Closes-Bug: #1363262

commit_message:
ofagent: Enable local arp responder for TYPE_FLAT

handling TYPE_FLAT is particularly useful because,
as stated in README, a flat provider network is
the recommended way to provide public network connectivity
for ofagent.

Related: blueprint ofagent-l2pop
Related: blueprint ofagent-merge-bridges
Change-Id: I4f9145ecb6ade44fc884ce7f8842f5e33385391e

commit_message:
IloVirtualMediaAgent deploy driver

This commit introduces a new deploy driver which uses iLO virtual
media to boot up proliant baremetal nodes, and uses agent to deploy
the baremetal nodes.

This patch also changes agent pxe config template slightly, so that
the names of agent ramdisk parameters generated in code and those
expected by agent ramdisk are same.

Change-Id: Ia5677dff294bc146b864bed180fbda939cf9bb38
Implements: blueprint ilo-virtualmedia-ipa

commit_message:
Fix for host env leak into grub

While building images in a dual boot host,
/dev/sda is leaking into build's grub config.
It is visible in the logs that the commands
GRUB-INSTALL and GRUB-MKCONFIG probes Host OS environment.
This is avoided by setting grub_disable_os_prober
to true in /default/grub config file.

Change-Id: I7408de7b3bc8a62f8bf103f00a88a596f988353c
Closes-Bug: 1166491

IloVirtualMediaIscsi deploy driver

This commit introduces a new iLo deploy driver which uses virtual
media to boot up proliant baremetal nodes, and uses iSCSI to deploy
the baremetal nodes.

subject: Fix WSGI mapping for SwiftAuthError exception
revisions:
[{'created': '2014-08-01 13:44:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Inappropriate WSGI mapping for SwiftAuthError that leads to HTTP 401

Reasons:
 - When regular user tries to access admin API endpoints Trove
   will raise H401 exception (Unauthorized)
   if there are some problems with Swift.
 - This issue violates RFC 2616.

Changes:
 - SwiftAuthError should only be a representation
   of HTTP 401 Unauthorized that would come from Swift.
 - For other reasons Trove should raise SwiftInteractionError,
   that is mapped to HTTP 400 BadRequest.

Change-Id: I17ea97f4904b2c6980723ede7f77f3d008bae6e3
Closes-Bug: #1351302
', 'number': 1}, {'created': '2014-08-01 14:54:28.000000000', 'files': ['trove/common/exception.py', 'trove/common/wsgi.py', 'trove/backup/models.py'], 'message': 'Fix WSGI mapping for SwiftAuthError exception

Reasons:
 - When regular user tries to access admin API endpoints Trove
   will raise H401 exception (Unauthorized)
   if there are some problems with Swift.
 - This issue violates RFC 2616.

Changes:
 - SwiftAuthError should only be a representation
   of HTTP 401 Unauthorized that would come from Swift.
 - For other reasons Trove should raise SwiftInteractionError,
   that is mapped to HTTP 400 BadRequest.

Change-Id: I17ea97f4904b2c6980723ede7f77f3d008bae6e3
Closes-Bug: #1351302
', 'number': 2}]
commit_message:
Fix WSGI mapping for SwiftAuthError exception

Reasons:
 - When regular user tries to access admin API endpoints Trove
   will raise H401 exception (Unauthorized)
   if there are some problems with Swift.
 - This issue violates RFC 2616.

Changes:
 - SwiftAuthError should only be a representation
   of HTTP 401 Unauthorized that would come from Swift.
 - For other reasons Trove should raise SwiftInteractionError,
   that is mapped to HTTP 400 BadRequest.

Change-Id: I17ea97f4904b2c6980723ede7f77f3d008bae6e3
Closes-Bug: #1351302

commit_message:
Don't pass pipe when filtering messages in the Redis driver

The pipe param was unnused in the message listing filter,
and so was removed.

Change-Id: I846dcdb75f04429b409fd5f55f563de6aa7b796e

commit_message:
Removing test_duration variable from bench/consumer.py

Variable test_duration is not necessary and we can use conf.time directly
 in the actual parameters.

Change-Id: I2747a300ae0c4155e1f50aad31ac88f6510753bd
Closes-Bug: #1361302
